src: à    Músá    wɛ̃́-ɛ̃̀    à    Ríhnátà  nɛ́  kúg-rì.
trs: Musa hit Rihnata with a stone.'\footnotemark \footnotetext{Proper names are usually preceded by the 3\textsc{sg} pronoun\textit{ à} as shown in \REF{ex:19.pacchiarotti}. This \textit{à} is not a case marker; it occurs before any proper name in all syntactic roles (S, A, O).}

(`Musa hit Rihnata with it'.)\footnotemark \footnotetext{The set III 3\textsc{sg} object pronoun -\textit{à} indexed in the verb in \sectref{§4.1:alignment.pacchiarotti} undergoes the same phonological process observed for the affirmative marker \textit{-à} in \sectref{§4.1:alignment.pacchiarotti}. When the shape of an immediately-preceding verb root is CV, the  set III 3\textsc{sg} pronoun \textit{-à} takes the form of a copy of the last vowel of the verb root, as in \REF{ex:20.pacchiarotti} where -\textit{à > -ɛ̃̀}{ because the verb root is CV and the last vowel is} {\textit{ɛ̃}}{. If the contiguous verb root is not CV, then the 3\textsc{sg} bound pronoun surfaces as -}{\textit{à(-là)}} {as in} {\REF{ex:22.pacchiarotti}} {and} {\REF{ex:24.pacchiarotti}}.{ (Manuel Otero, p.c.).}}
She swiped the blood off the cloth.
(`She wiped the blood off it.')
I sent the child home.'\footnotemark \footnotetext{In \ili{Mooré}, the verb \textit{tʊ́mè} can mean `work' but also `send someone'.}
(`I sent the child to it.')
Musa showed goats to the dog.
Musa showed them to the dog.
Musa showed goats to it (i.e. to the dog).
Musa fed the sheep (plural) to the lion.
Musa fed the sheep to it (to the lion).
? `Musa fed the lion to them (to the sheep)' not *`Musa fed them (the sheep) to the lion.
(`I gave yesterday the pot to the woman.')
(`I gave to the woman yesterday the pot.')
